III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157
Section Health services; policies and procedures
Description (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures that address all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/23/2025 at 8:40 PM, a youth was experiencing chest pain
and requested to be sent to the ER. Youth has a known history of
asthma and did not have home medications available on-site. The
pain was not relieved by a nebulizer treatment administered at the
facility. The facility supervisor speculated the episode may have
been anxiety-related and noted that youth had repeatedly
requested hospital care, which the supervisor declined. Another
staff member requested the youth be transported to the ER due to
persistent symptoms. These requests were denied by the
supervisor, who expressed the repeated appeals for outside
medical attention were "getting on her nerves" and dismissed
them as non-emergency. A phone triage was completed on youth,
supervisor was instructed to administer a saline nebulizer
treatment to combat any congestion and TUMS for any indigestion
following that night's nachos for dinner. When symptoms remained
unresolved, supervisor was directed to transport youth to the
nearest hospital for further evaluation. Youth was subsequently
taken to the hospital. Later that day, the other staff member
recalled that youth began complaining of chest pain as early as
7:00 PM—nearly 1 hour and 40 minutes before supervision was
contacted. It was confirmed that youth repeatedly requested to be
transported to the ER and those requests were denied by the
supervisor, despite youth’s persistent symptoms and visible
physical distress. Youth was "begging" the supervisor for nearly
two hours before finally contacting the nurse for approval for ER
transport.
Investigation Interviews:
Nurse was interviewed via phone on July 15, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Nurse reported that since
she was involved in the last investigation, 2025SIC0000730, she
needed to address this concern due to potential medical neglect.
She reported during the previous investigation, she found the
facility is not following this written medical policy for emergency
needs. Nurse reported in April 2025, Youth A was placed at the
facility. She reported that upon admission, it was found Youth A
had asthma, and his mother did not bring his required inhalers
2

right away. Nurse reported on April 23, 2025, she received a call
from Supervisor around 8:40pm to report Youth A had unrelieved
chest pain after receiving a nebulizer treatment. Shre reported
Supervisor believed it to be from anxiety or possible indigestion
from the nachos dinner that evening. Nurse reported she
instructed Supervisor to give Youth A antacids and oxygen. She
reported when she checked back in, Youth A was still in pain and
instructed Supervisor to take Youth A into the emergency room.
Nurse reported Supervisor reported she would take him, but
hoped it was not a waste of time. She reported Youth A was in the
hospital for a couple of hours and was diagnosed with generalized
chest pain. Nurse reported the next day, Mother called and was
angry. She reported Mother was demanding to know why she was
not told that Youth A was going to the hospital for chest pains and
breathing issues. Nurse reported Supervisor had called Mother
first and asked her to bring Youth A’s medications to the facility,
but it was Youth A who called Mother when he was at the hospital.
She reported she checked in on Youth A on April 24, 2025, to see
how he was feeling. Nurse reported Youth A reported he was
feeling fine now and denied needing any other medical care. She
reported she did ask Youth A what happened the night before and
reported he wanted to go to the hospital for chest pains and
breathing issues, but Supervisor said no and it would be a waste
of time, but Staff 1 advocated for him to go to the hospital, which
he eventually did. Nurse reported she spoke with Staff 1 on April
24, 2025, about what occurred on April 23, 2025. She reported
Staff 1 reported around 7pm, Youth A was having chest pains,
and he reported this to Supervisor. Staff 1 reported he told
Supervisor that Youth A needed to go to the hospital, but
Supervisor said no. He reported Supervisor told him she had to
contact Nurse first per policy. Staff 1 told Nurse that Youth A did
eventually go to the hospital, but it was two hours after his
symptoms started, and he felt it was too long of a wait. Nurse was
asked about getting Youth A’s medications from his mother, and
she reported he was without his medications for a few days. She
reported they attempted to ask for these medications numerous
times and were going to have them re-prescribed the next day
when the doctor was at the facility. When asked about the
nebulizer treatment, Nurse explained this is onsite for anyone to
use if a youth is having a breathing problem. She reported
Supervisors are trained to administer this.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at his home on July 11,
2025, by MDHHS Worker. This consultant attempted to be
available by phone, but Mother refused to allow this
consultant to be on the phone during the interview. The
3

following interview details are from notes by MDHHS Worker
who completed the said interview. MDHHS Worker asked
Youth A to explain what happened in April, 2025 while he was at
the facility and having an asthma attack. Youth A reported around
7:30pm, he started having chest pains and trouble breathing. He
told Staff 1 about his concerns, and Staff 1 took him to see Nurse.
Youth A reported Nurse provided him with a breathing treatment
and an inhaler and then was told to go back to his room. He
reported he is still not feeling well after the treatment and told Staff
1 about it. Youth A reported Staff 1 told Supervisor Youth A
needed to go to the hospital, and Youth A was finally taken at
8pm. He reported he received treatment for his asthma while at
the ER and was discharged a few hours later. Youth A reported
Supervisor told him she did not want him to have Youth A go, and
it would be a waste of money. He reported he otherwise felt safe
at the facility and had no other medical concerns while he was
there.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on July
15, 2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor
reported she was the supervisor on shift on April 23, 2025. She
reported she received a call from Staff 1, who reported Youth A
was playing a board game with him and started to complain of
chest pain. Supervisor reported she knew Youth A had asthma
and they were still waiting for Mother to bring the inhaler up to the
facility. She reported it was approved by Administrator for Youth A
to use this nebulizer treatment at the facility. Supervisor reported
she administered the treatment and verified the medication was
up-to-date. She reported after the treatment, Youth A went back to
his pod. Shre reported she waited for about 15-20 minutes to see
if the symptoms had improved, but they did not. Staff 1 reported to
Supervisor, Youth A was still complaining of chest pain, and Staff
1 felt Youth A needed to go to the hospital. Supervisor denied
Youth A ever directly asking her to go to the hospital or telling him
that he was not going to go. She reported she told Staff 1 she was
going to call Nurse. Supervisor contacted Nurse, who asked
Supervisor to check his vitals and report back. Nurse advised
Supervisor to give Youth A Tums, administer treatment, and
Gatorade, and if he was not feeling better, to take him to the ER in
about an hour. About forty-five minutes later Supervisor chose for
Youth A to go to the hospital. She admitted she did comment on
hoping the trip to the hospital was not a waste, but it's better to be
safe than sorry. Supervisor denied ever noting it was a waste of
money. She was asked about contacting Mother, and she
reported she contacted Mother at the site of Youth A’s symptoms
and asked for her to bring his medications. Supervisor reported
4

Mother told her she would bring the medications tomorrow
morning, and Supervisor did confirm with Mother that Youth A
received a nebulizer treatment. She reported she attempted to call
Mother twice when Youth A was going to the hospital, but she
could not get through to her. Supervisor was asked about the
general understanding of the facility’s medical policy, and she
reported she had an understanding of the policy. She reported
that staff on site should try to meet the youths’ medical needs first
before sending them out for medical treatment. She explained if
the nurse is on site, they will triage in person, and if not, then this
is completed over the phone. When asked who decided if a youth
should go to the hospital, she said it’s a collaboration between
supervision and the nurses. Supervisor agreed that supervisors
can decide to take a youth to the hospital even if the nurse does
not agree. When asked about communication and documentation
of medical issues, Supervisor reported she sent an email directly
to Administrator. She reported she did not do an exact incident
report because everything was laid out in her email about the
events that occurred. When asked to provide a timeline of the
events that took place she reported the following: 8 pm was
notified by Staff 1 that Youth A was having chest pains; 8:10pm
provided a nebulizer treatment to Youth A; 8:20pm called Mother
about medication and treatment; 8:30pm Staff 1 reported Youth A
was still reporting chest pain; 8:40pm Supervisor called Nurse;
9:20pm Youth A was sent to the hospital for further care.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 21,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported he
was playing cards with Youth A on April 2025, when Youth A
started to complain his chest was hurting. He reported he could
not remember the exact time of day this occurred, but believes it
was around 7pm. Staff 1 reported when Youth A started to
complain, he grabbed Youth A some water and called Supervisor.
He reported Supervisor gave the direction to give Youth A some
Tums because it may be heartburn, and call back in a few minutes
if that does not give relief. Staff 1 reported Youth A still
complained of pain, so he called Supervisor back, who then
contacted Nurse. Supervisor then brought Youth A down to the
nurses’ station to receive a nebulizer treatment. Staff 1 reported
Supervisor was in contact with Nurse and provided Nurse with
Youth A’s vital information. He reported Youth A’s symptoms did
not get better, and Staff 1 was given directions to bring Youth A to
the hospital. Staff 1 reported he called Mother on the pod before
they left for the hospital, and she met them at the hospital. He
reported he could not remember exactly when they left for the
hospital, but it was believed that it was a little before 10pm. Staff 1
5

denied Youth A ever directly asking to see a physical. He reported
when he was talking to Supervisor about the situation, Staff 1 was
the one who brought Youth A to the hospital because he could
see Youth A was not getting any relief. Staff 1 reported Supervisor
was following the policy, where she contacted Nurse and tried to
help with Youth A’s symptoms at the facility before rushing to the
hospital. He reported Youth A told him he felt safe with Staff 1
advocating for him. Staff 1 reported the medical policy is for staff
to first see if they can help the youth’s medical concern and
contact Supervisor if a youth has a more urgent need. He reported
Supervisor is to then contact Nurse and see about next steps, and
can bring a youth to the hospital if deemed necessary. Staff 1
reported he felt the situation was handled appropriately and in a
timely manner. He reported he never talked to Nurse about this
situation. Staff 1 reported there was no one else involved in this
situation, and the other youth in the pod were in bed when these
medical decisions were being made. He reported he cannot
remember exactly what Supervisor said about bringing Youth A to
the hospital. Staff 1 reported Supervisor commented on something
along the lines of hoping this situation is not a waste of time, but
better safe than sorry. He reported this was never directly stated
to Youth A and could not remember the context of the statement
or when it was stated.
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
July 15, 2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Administrator confirmed the facility is actively working on redoing
their emergency medical care policy and will be retraining staff
from the findings in special investigation 2025SIC0000730. He
reported he was notified of Youth A going to the hospital on April
23, 2025, and because Supervisor told her she could use her
email to him as the incident report. Administrator reported the
court permitted him to allow a youth to receive medication
treatment, such as a nebulizer, when the parent is not following
through with giving prescribed medications. He reported
permission was granted for Youth A to receive a nebulizer
treatment, as it notes in his chart that he has asthma and staff
have been attempting to obtain his inhalers from Mother for a few
days.
Mother was interviewed face to face at his home on July 11,
2025, by MDHHS Worker. This consultant attempted to be
available by phone, but Mother refused to allow this
consultant to be on the phone during the interview. The
following interview details are from notes by MDHHS Worker
who completed the said interview. Mother reported on April 23,
6

2025, she was contacted by Supervisor who reported Youth A
was having Asthma issues but was okay. About ten minutes later,
Mother received a call from Staff 1 reporting Youth A was not okay
and he was going to take him to the hospital despite being told not
to due to protocol. Mother reported she went to the hospital and
stayed with Youth A until he was discharged. She reported she
believed this was between 8pm-9pm, and he was discharged
before midnight. Mother reported Youth A told her Supervisor had
told him he was not going to the hospital because it would be a
waste of money. She then stated she contacted Supervisor the
next day to confront her about what happened and not calling her
back to tell her Youth A was not okay. Mother reported Supervisor
denied ever telling Youth A that it was a waste of money and
stated she tried to call Mother but could not get through. MDHHS
Worker asked Mother about Youth A’s medication, and she stated
he has an inhaler and Singular. Mother reported Youth A was not
prescribed a nebulizer and did not know whose treatment he was
given. MDHHS Worker asked Mother if she had dropped his
medications off at the facility before the hospital visit, and she
stated she does not remember the exact date she dropped the
medications off at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 21,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported
he is frustrated with being at the facility because he does not like
the food and would rather be home. He reported he does not feel
unsafe at the facility. Youth B reported he has never had a
medical emergency at the facility or any medical issue concerns.
He reported there was one youth on his pod; he could not
remember his name, that sprained his ankle while playing
basketball, and the facility provided that youth with a brace. Youth
B denied ever seeing any other medical emergencies at the
facility.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 21,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C reported
he feels safe at the facility. He reported he has never had a
medical emergency while at the facility. He reported he is aware
he can go see a nurse at the facility or ask staff to bring him to see
a physician if needed. Youth C reported one of his peers went to
the hospital when he hurt his foot while playing basketball. He
reported he could not remember the youth’s name but noted staff
responded quickly when that youth hurt his foot and took him to
the hospital right away.
7

Tour of Facility
A tour of the facility occurred on July 15, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. The nurse’s station was
viewed by Administrator and Supervisor. The nebulizer machine
was set up. There was a box of expired cartages, but it was
verified by Administrator and Supervisors that they are not being
used and need to be disposed of. This consultant watched
Administrator dispose of the expired cartages. Supervisor reported
when she gave the treatment to Youth A in April, 2025 the
medication cartage had not expired as she verified it.
Administrator reported they are working with the health
department to get more cartages, but there have been some
barriers with getting a consistent doctor to prescribe them.
Documentation Reviewed
- Facility’s Medical Emergency Policy- This policy notes
that if a youth or staff member requires emergency medical
care the following steps shall be taken: 1. Determine the
nature of the injury or illness with a as much detail as
possible. 2. Notify appropriate medical personnel or
emergency medical ambulance services, depending upon
the extent of the illness or injury. 3. If the youth or staff
member can be moved, he/she should be assisted to the
appropriate medical services for diagnosis and/or
treatment. 4. If the youth/ staff member cannot be moved,
emergency medical services shall be brought to the injured
party. 5. The Superintendent shall be notified of all severe
medical incidents and an Incident Report shall be filed
before the end of the shift. 6. 911 shall be used for all
emergency calls.
- Facility’s Resident Management/Resident Rights
policy- This document outlines that medical care shall be
provided for all youth and no youth shall be denied access
to a licensed physician upon request.
- Bronson Hospital After Visit summary for Youth A- This
after visit documentation from the hospital shows Youth A
was brought into the hospital on April 23, 2025 and seen by
a doctor at 10:32pm and was discharged at 11:36pm.
There were no acute medical needs found, and Youth A
was provided with a steroid per Mother’s request. Mother
was noted to be at the hospital with Youth A.
8

- Email to Administration team from Supervisor dated
April 24, 2025, 12:23 am- This email is the details that
were sent out about Youth A’s medical care needs and
going to the hospital. This email notes the exact events
noted from Supervisor’s interview. This email was noted to
be the incident report.
- Email to Administration team from Nurse dated April
24, 2025, 1:09 am- Nurse emailed in response to
Supervisor’s initial email noting that Supervisor did
everything correctly per her advice.
- Email to Administration team from Nurse dated April
24, 2025, 11:13 am- Nurse emailed noting she had
followed up with Youth A, Supervisor, Staff 1, and Mother
about the events that occurred the night prior. Nurse first
provided her details of the steps she took when Supervisor
called her on April 23, 2025 at 8:40pm. She noted within
this email Supervisor believed it was more of an anxiety
attack but had given a nebulizer treatment to Youth A prior
to her calling Nurse. Nurse reported she asked for vitals
which Supervisor provided and deemed them to be stable.
She noted she “could see Youth A was in pain but not
actively in distress that would warrant calling 911”. Nurse
noted all the triage medical questions she went through
with Supervisor on Youth A and noted Supervisor followed
all her prompts. Nurse noted her conversation with Mother
who was very upset. Within the email Nurse wrote, “I
genuinely do understand her concerns, but in my
professional opinion- I believed Youth A received the
proper care in a good amount of time. It is not our protocol
to send children to the hospital without doing some form of
an assessment. Youth A’s vitals were stable enough for
Supervisor to assess in the building, so we were well within
our consent to treat until we could not anymore, in which
the ER was then suggestion and Youth A was taken to
Bronson Er.”
- Text messages between Nurse and Supervisor from
April 23, 2025- Supervisor started off with sending Nurse
the medical vitals of Youth A. Nurse reported they were
great and he needs to do slow deep breaths. Supervisor
verified this was being done. Nure reported, “This sounds
9

dumb- but you can give him a Gatorade as a placebo and
see if he improves. IT might trick his mind. If he’s still in
pain and symptomatic by 9:30pm and saying his check
hurts I’d take him to the ER. He doesn’t sound like he is
having an asthma attack.” There was continued
communication about Youth A’s health and Supervisor
verified Youth A’s health. Supervisor noted Staff 1
continued to state Youth A needs to be sent to the hospital
and “it was getting annoying.” Nurse wrote back stating, “I
don’t want him to have an episode but his vitals are stable.
Staff 1 is probably just freaking out. I’ve seen people in
worse shape get discharged but to be fair I wasn’t there
and I don’t know if they were running playing, etc.”
Supervisor responded with, “He was playing a board game
and it started out of no where. It will probably be a waste of
time to send him, but better safe than sorry.” Nurse
responded with,” Yes better safe than Sorry! If he does to
the ER just mentioned he just received a Neb.” Nurse then
continued to talk to Supervisor about what to say to the ER.
Supervisor verified via text message to Nurse that Youth A
was brought into the hospital. There was no time stamp
dating these text messages.
- Supervisor Human Resource File- Supervisor has no
disciplinary actions noted within her HR file. She is in
compliance with all trainings. Her last medical training was
noted to be 12/13/2024 and her Safety and Security
Emergency Procedures training was completed on
06/12/2024.
- Youth A’s File- Permission to provide emergency
medications was provided within the file.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with Supervisor following their
medical policy. It was never found that Youth A directly stated he
wanted to see a physician, but Supervisor took the situation
serious with contacting Nurse for further support on Youth A’s
medical concerns. Supervisor also made the call to bring him to
the hospital sooner than when Nurse suggested to bring Youth A.
Technical Assistance:
The facility was provided technical assistance to make sure to
continue to update their medical policy as they are doing within
the corrective action plan for Special Investigation
10

2025SIC0000730. The facility needs to be clear on the
expectation of the incident report, and it is suggested to do an
actual incident report document rather than just an email. The
facility was also provided feedback to make sure medications they
have on hand that could be used to treat youth are not expired.
The nebulizer medication seen in the medical room was found to
be expired but it was unknown what date the medication Youth A
received for his treatment. The facility did dispose of the expired
medication during the onsite visit.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
